channel.title: Taking User Input [Help]

item.title: Taking User Input [Help]
item.dc:creator: @Stork Stork
item.description:
@Stork wrote:

yeah seriously guys don’t you know java object creation takes AGES and if you create an object is NEVER GETS REMOVE FROM MEMORY?!
not even by the java garbage collector !!!
!!!

Read full topic

item.title: Taking User Input [Help]
item.dc:creator: @Ollie Ollie
item.description:
@Ollie wrote:

Silver Lining:

way to use needless local variables.

System.out.println("you put " + System.console().readLine(“enter something”));

was that really necessary?

Read full topic

item.title: Taking User Input [Help]
item.dc:creator: @Greeny Greeny
item.description:
@Greeny wrote:

It might have already been said but, a Buffered reader would be better. Although in a small application like this a scanner is fine. But if you want what we call “Good coding practice” I’d recommend using the above.

Read full topic

item.title: Taking User Input [Help]
item.dc:creator: @Yz85Racer Yz85Racer
item.description:
@Yz85Racer wrote:

[quote=“lawl, post:2, topic:148488”][quote author=Yz85Racer link=topic=203559.msg1797250#msg1797250 date=1191401325]
I think he was calling me out when I think I could of just done InputStreamReader in = new InputStreamReader();
Instead of wrapping it with a BufferedReader.
[/quote]
err no he means console is static and only created once, and retrieved with System.console(), so it takes less memory, because you dont make another reader object.[/quote]
Ohhh, haha I getcha’ now.

Read full topic

item.title: Taking User Input [Help]
item.dc:creator: @Yz85Racer Yz85Racer
item.description:
@Yz85Racer wrote:

I think he was calling me out when I think I could of just done InputStreamReader in = new InputStreamReader();
Instead of wrapping it with a BufferedReader.

item.title: Taking User Input [Help]
item.dc:creator: @Silver_Lining Silver Lining
item.description:
@Silver_Lining wrote:

The bug was in this line:

System.in.print("You entered: " + n1); Otherwise, it’s fine.[quote=“Ollie, post:2, topic:148440”]try

java.io.Console console = System.console();
String input = console.readLine(“enter something”);
System.out.println("you put " + input);[/quote]If you’re going to bitch about Yz85Racer using up memory, then I’ll bitch you out about it too: way to use needless local variables.

Read full topic

item.description:
@Javacisnotrecognized wrote:

Ollie:

way to waste memory creating new objects like that

If memory usage was a concern, he would be porting the program from C++ to C, not from C++ to Java.

item.title: Taking User Input [Help]
item.dc:creator: @yakman yakman
item.description:
@yakman wrote:

theres loads of ways in that post above, i prefer bufferedreader, but just my opinion

by the way, the reason ‘System.in.read();’ didnt work for you, is because it read the next char and changes it to a byte, so from 0 < c < 255, you could type-case it to char to get the character again, (unless you use a character from unicode, then stuff would get a lot more complicated, might work though, never tried it)

Read full topic

item.title: Taking User Input [Help]
item.dc:creator: @Yz85Racer Yz85Racer
item.description:
@Yz85Racer wrote:

[code]import java.io.*;
public class Test {

public static void main(String[] args) {
	try {
		BufferedReader in = new BufferedReader(new InputStreamReader(System.in));
		System.out.print("Please enter a number : ");
		String i = in.readLine();
		System.out.println("You entered : " + i);
	} catch(IOException e) {
		e.printStackTrace();
	}
}

}
[/code]

Read full topic

item.title: Taking User Input [Help]
item.dc:creator: @Pwnd Pwnd
item.description:
@Pwnd wrote:

Or you can use Scanner.

Scanner s = new Scanner(System.in); int i = s.nextInt();
Something like that.

item.title: Taking User Input [Help]
item.dc:creator: @Daed Daed
item.description:
@Daed wrote:

Hello, i’ve just started to try to learn Java, and im having a bit of trouble in taking input, in C++ i would put:

#include <iostream> using namespace std; int main() { int n1; cout << "Please enter a number: "; cin >> n1; cout << "You entered " + n1 << endl; return 0; }

So in java i thought it would be something like:

class TakingInput
{  
        public static void main(String args[])
        {
           int n1;
           System.out.println("Please enter a number: ");
           n1 = System.in.read();
           System.in.print("You entered: " + n1);           
        }
}

I’ve tried google but nothing helped

Read full topic
